image.alt_text: Photo by Clarissa Victoria on October 24, 2020.
image.caption:
Christianity and colonisation have always gone hand-in-hand, a weaponised doctrine which overthrows local belief systems in favour of the one European almighty God. As Sepie (2017, p. 7) writes in 'More than Stories, More than Myths: Animal/Human/Nature(s) in Traditional Ecological Worldviews':⠀⠀
⠀⠀
"Consider the way that early Christianity was moved through the world: step one, exorcise local gods and spirits by insisting that demons and angels are the only possible supernatural beings. Step two, replace local systems of belief with the fear of, and obedience toward, an Old Testament God, and the attached cosmology, which finishes the process of exorcism…animate or sentient aspects of nature, including weather, features of the landscape, and the concept of other creatures as speaking, acting, or as spiritually endowed beings, remained possible only in the provinces of myth and fiction." ⠀⠀
⠀⠀
Christianity is predicated upon the god-embodiment of the man Jesus Christ, and is therefore human-centric. In contrast, most indigenous cosmologies are Land-based, animist, and emphasises the interconnectedness of humans with all of creation. For me personally, wellness is the reclaiming and understanding of this truth which indigenous elders have understood throughout the ages; that we do not exist in a world made for humans, but in a greater web of purpose and interconnectedness with all earthly beings. ⠀
⠀
Humans are not the centre of the universe, and we must learn our humble place. ⠀
⠀⠀
Photograph of Nias women in Sumatra, Indonesia, unknown source (retrieved from Pinterest).⠀⠀
⠀⠀
#decolonize #spirituality #indigenousspirituality #morethanmyths #decolonizeyourmind #decolonizespirituality #decolonizechristianity #ancestors #animism #decolonizewellness #indonesian #womenofcolour #sumatra #indonesianwomen #indigeneity

image.alt_text: Photo shared by Liisa-Ravna Finbog on June 26, 2021 tagging @olehenrikbl, and @oslopride. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and outdoors.
image.caption:
Systems of gender discrimination and heteropatriarchy, which is basically a socio-political system in which cisgender males and heterosexuals have authority over cisgender females, gender identities and sexual orientations, is a constituent process in the colonization of Indigenous nations.

Similar to many other Indigenous nations, women in Sápmi historically had a form of equality with men, characterized by complementary domains, roles and tasks. That's not to say that Sámi society prior to colonization was matriarchal, but there is evidence to suggest that with colonization also came a change in the structural relations between genders and sexualities.

Heteropatriarchy have worked, and very much continue to marginalize and invalidate Indigenous queerness. Often we are told that being queer or the notion of queerness works against Indigenous and  traditional values. But ask yourself this, is it traditional to adhere to values introduced and enforced by colonialism? 

The month of June has universally been recognized as a time to celebrate the diversity of sexuality and gender, subverting the tropes that continue to push the narrative that the world we live in is intrinsically binary with only two genders, and where the only relationships approved of and validated happens between a binary opposition.

In that sense, Pride should also be an important decolonizing event. 

I really hope that whatever you do this month to celebrate or commemorate Pride, you do it in the spirit of decolonization.

Start by centering indigeneity and include Two-Spirit, queer, intersection and asexual as equally valid ways in which people choose to identify, or more to the point , in which Indigenous people choose to identify.

By using 2slgbtqia+ you help build space where Indigenous communities may feel included, and if that's not celebrating the essence of Pride, I really don't know what is.

📸 @koronja____ 

@oslopride 2019

#sámi #sápmi #pride #2slgbtqia #indigenousqueer #samiqueer #decolonizingpride #decolonizingspaces #indigeneity #fluidity #indigeniussolidarity

image.alt_text: Photo by 🌼batultrueheart🌼 in Occupied Huichin Ohlone Territory. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and indoor.
image.caption:
Happy #indigenouspeoplesday and since I missed it yesterday, happy #nationalcomingoutday. For me, and for many, these two identities, #indigenous and #queer, go hand in hand.  If you know a little about my life story, you know that I could have ended up “white” and “straight” lol. I grew up with only one side of my family, the white Latina side, and was the only brown person. I grew up Southern Baptist. I was taught from an early age that homosexuality was “wrong in God’s eyes.” As a little one, I took that to believe that *I* was wrong in God’s eyes. I didn’t come out to my family as queer until I was 32 years old. This was the same year, 10 years ago now,  that I met my father and I learned that we’re Yaqui. Of course, I’ve always been Indigenous, not only by blood but through my natural connection and inclination to the earth, as well as to the ethereal. My queerness, my two-spiritness, is an expression of my #wholeness and that’s where it ties into my #indigeneity.
In 2014 I made a public prayer to “be who I truly am’”. This prayer was my humble attempt to heal from the lifetimes, over 500 years and over 4,000 ancestors, who were either *forced* to assimilate aka to be who they were not OR they were the *enforcers*, the colonizers, the killers of wholeness. The more Indigenous I’m *being* the more queer I feel, the more *real* I feel. I’m so grateful to be me. To have finally found me, after over 40 years. To be out. To be whole. I’m so grateful to be Indigenous or more accurately #Yo’eme and I’m also so grateful to be queer AF. I’m so grateful to live (loud and proud) and *be* who I TRULY am.
#indigenouspeoplesday 
#nationalcomingoutday 
#queerdeerhere
✨🌈🦌✨🌈🦌✨🌈✨🦌✨🌈🦌✨

image.alt_text: Photo by Museum of Anthropology in Museum of Anthropology.
image.caption:
This subversive pair of moccasins in MOA's collections was created by Vancouver-based Anishinabe artist Charlene Vickers. Her works concern memory and the expression of Indigenous identity, and how materials themselves can carry social and cultural significance. Constructed from Sleeman beer cartons, denim and glass beads, these moccasins are a criticism of the commodification of Indigenous culture. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
In this thought-provoking work, Vickers reinvents a typical “Native” object sold to tourists by incorporating materials that draw from urban Indigenous experiences. They confront stereotypes and expose issues of racism and marginalization facing Indigenous peoples. The moccasins may not be wearable, but, according to the artist, they "tell a story of power dynamics, loss of culture and finding personal strength."⁣⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣⁣
Sleeman Makazin. [MOA Collections 2887/1 a-b]. By Charlene Vickers (@vickers.charlene). 2004. Anishinabe. Vancouver: British Columbia. 📷: Kyla Bailey.⁣⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣⁣
#MOAFromHome #museumfromhome #museum #moa #ubc #britishcolumbia #indigenousart #museumofanthropology #NationalIndigenousHistoryMonth #NIHM #charlenevickers #anishinabe #womenartists #womeninmuseums #indigeneity⁣ #moccasins #textiles #shoes

image.alt_text: Photo by Nia Tero on February 26, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and outdoors.
image.caption:
It's #FellowsFriday and we’ve got some incredible talent to share with you! @_lehuauakea_, a PNW Art Fellow, is a mixed-Native Hawaiian kapa maker and interdisciplinary artist from Pāpaʻikou on Moku O Keawe, the Big Island of Hawaiʻi. Lehua’s Kānaka Maoli family descends from several lineages connected to Maui, Kauaʻi, Kohala, and Hāmākua where their family resides to this day.

Through a range of craft-based media, their art serves as a means of exploring cultural and biological ecologies, spectrums of Indigeneity, and what it means to live within the context of contemporary environmental degradation. With a particular focus on the labor-intensive making of ʻohe kāpala, kapa cloth, and natural pigments, Lehua is able to breathe new life into patterns and traditions practiced for generations. Through these acts of resilience that help forge deeper relationships with ʻāina, this mode of Indigenous storytelling is carried well into the future.

image.alt_text: Photo by Otséémėhé'e/Niiswinikese/Court in Hollywood Boulevard with @thejasongoodrich, and @indeclineofficial. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, people walking, street and road.
image.caption:
Are you outraged by this?
•
Imagine what it feels like to be an Indigenous woman living in a society that is more outraged over a red hat than if you go missing or if you are murdered.
•
"Hate Breed" by @indeclineofficial
•
Photo by: @thejasongoodrich
•
#MMIW #MMIWG #Dogwalks #INDECLINE #Art #HateBreed #PerformanceArt #Hollywood #HollywoodBlvd #Walkoffame #IndigenousResistance #Native #Indigeneity #StillHere #ProtectOurWomen #NoMoreStolenSisters  #Justice4Henny #HennyStrong #HennyScott #HannaHarris #SayTheirNames #NorthernCheyenne #Tsitsistas
•
(Purse made by Michelle Kipp (Guzman), skirt made by me, and hat made by China 🤭)

image.alt_text: Photo by Jamie John on July 09, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and indoor.
image.caption:
Today marks the end of my first session as both an arts educator and an Indigenous educator. I’ll get all new student on Monday but I’m not sure if “baamaapi” will get an easier. The hardest part out of all of this is not knowing if I’m doing my job well, working to de-center myself as an instructor while also giving a part of myself away to all of my students. 

In class, I talk of the wild rice beds along the river, about the danger of pipelines like Line 3 and Line 5 along the Straits of Mackinaw. I address the wild peppermint next to the lake as my friend, I teach animal names in Anishinaabemowin and greet my kids with “Aaniin, boozhoo!” I am one of the first generations of Anishinaabeg to teach my language in classroom on my ancestral homelands without fear. I talk about who my people are and I tell them about how we lived along with the land. I talk to them about the crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, two-spirits, and trans femmes and the legacy of residential schools. I talk about what the world was like before Columbus got lost or before we knew the footsteps of European settlers. I talk about queerness and gender. Most of my kids are only 10 or 11, so they ask about Pocahontas—and I tell them the truth. Her name was Matoaka and she was taken from her people, married someone she didn’t love, and was buried under an English name. I say “miigwetch” and “nishin!” and teach them how to introduce themselves in Anishinaabemowin. Everyday I’m proud to be Anishinaabe, everyday I’m proud to be Indigenous, and everyday I’m proud to be NDN. 

This is my version of reclamation. This is how I assert my Indigeneity in inherently colonized spaces. This is how we unsettle the settler frame of mind. 

#unsettlethesettler #indigeneity #twospirit #arteducation
